questions.text: If a patient comes with acute abdomen, which of the following test(s) can be done in supine position?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The psoas sign, also known as Cope's psoas test or Obraztsova's sign, is a medical sign that indicates irritation to the iliopsoas group of hip flexors in the abdomen, and consequently indicates that the inflamed appendix is retrocaecal in orientation Rovsing sign: In supine position, palpation of the left lower quadrant of a person's abdomen increases the pain felt in the right lower quadrant, the patient is said to have a positive Rovsing's sign and may have appendicitis. The obturator sign or Cope's obturator test is an indicator of irritation to the obturator internus muscle . The technique for detecting the obturator sign, called the obturator test , is carried out on each leg in succession. The patient lies on her/his back with the hip and knee both flexed at ninety degrees. The examiner holds the patient's ankle with one hand and knee with the other hand. The examiner internally rotates the hip by moving the patient's ankle away from the patient's body while allowing the knee to move only inward. This is flexion and internal rotation of the hip. In the clinical context, it is performed when acute appendicitis is suspected Carnett's test is a simple clinical test in which abdominal tenderness is evaluated in supine position while the patient tenses the abdominal muscles. It is useful for differentiating abdominal wall pain from intra-abdominal pain Ballance sign: A dull percussion resonance sound heard on the right flank of a patient lying in the left decubitus position, an indication ofa ruptured spleen. The sound is caused by an accumulation of liquid blood on the right side and coagulated blood on theleft.
  • • The psoas sign, also known as Cope's psoas test or Obraztsova's sign, is a medical sign that indicates irritation to the iliopsoas group of hip flexors in the abdomen, and consequently indicates that the inflamed appendix is retrocaecal in orientation
  • • Rovsing sign: In supine position, palpation of the left lower quadrant of a person's abdomen increases the pain felt in the right lower quadrant, the patient is said to have a positive Rovsing's sign and may have appendicitis.
  • • The obturator sign or Cope's obturator test is an indicator of irritation to the obturator internus muscle . The technique for detecting the obturator sign, called the obturator test , is carried out on each leg in succession. The patient lies on her/his back with the hip and knee both flexed at ninety degrees. The examiner holds the patient's ankle with one hand and knee with the other hand. The examiner internally rotates the hip by moving the patient's ankle away from the patient's body while allowing the knee to move only inward. This is flexion and internal rotation of the hip. In the clinical context, it is performed when acute appendicitis is suspected
  • • Carnett's test is a simple clinical test in which abdominal tenderness is evaluated in supine position while the patient tenses the abdominal muscles. It is useful for differentiating abdominal wall pain from intra-abdominal pain
  • • Ballance sign: A dull percussion resonance sound heard on the right flank of a patient lying in the left decubitus position, an indication ofa ruptured spleen. The sound is caused by an accumulation of liquid blood on the right side and coagulated blood on theleft.

questions.text: What is true regarding frostbite injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Spontaneous recovery without any therapy is always the rule

options.label: C
options.text: Affected part shows erythema and edema in 1st and 2nd degree frostbites

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Frostbite injury
  • • Affects distal parts and exposed areas of limbs and face. Tissue injury occurs due to freezing and vasoconstriction In 1st and 2nd degree frostbite, Edema and redness is seen. In 3rd degree, hyperemia, edema and blisters/vesicles appear In 4th degree, gangrene and autoamputation can happen.
  • • Affects distal parts and exposed areas of limbs and face.
  • • Tissue injury occurs due to freezing and vasoconstriction
  • • In 1st and 2nd degree frostbite, Edema and redness is seen.
  • • In 3rd degree, hyperemia, edema and blisters/vesicles appear
  • • In 4th degree, gangrene and autoamputation can happen.
  • • Treatment includes rapid rewarming, analgesia, Aspirin, Topical antibiotics etc
  • • Treatment includes rapid rewarming, analgesia, Aspirin, Topical antibiotics etc

questions.text: True regarding pyogenic liver abscess is/are?

options.label: A
options.text: Always arise due to septic focus outside the hepatobiliary tree

options.label: B
options.text: Mostly seen in the left lobe

options.label: C
options.text: Associated with right sided pleural effusion

options.label: D
options.text: Antibiotics helpful even in severe cases before going for surgical drainage

options.label: E
options.text: Polymicrobial flora is seen in 40% cases

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Pyogenic liver abscess
  • • 50% are solitary, 50% multiple Mostly involve right lobe 40% are polymicrobial; E.coli is single MC organism Etiology for focus may be inside biliary tree or outside Presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain and constitutional symptoms Right sided pleural effusion is a known complication USG-or CT-guided aspiration is the IOC Most cases can be treated with high dose, broad spectrum antibiotics with or without percutaneous catheter drainage Surgery is done in abscess not amenable to percutaneous drainage, not responding to antibiotics and association with intra-abdominal disease.
  • • 50% are solitary, 50% multiple
  • • Mostly involve right lobe
  • • 40% are polymicrobial; E.coli is single MC organism
  • • Etiology for focus may be inside biliary tree or outside
  • • Presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain and constitutional symptoms
  • • Right sided pleural effusion is a known complication
  • • USG-or CT-guided aspiration is the IOC
  • • Most cases can be treated with high dose, broad spectrum antibiotics with or without percutaneous catheter drainage
  • • Surgery is done in abscess not amenable to percutaneous drainage, not responding to antibiotics and association with intra-abdominal disease.

questions.text: Opsite wound dressings
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Opsite post-operative wound dressings
  • • It’s a transparent, adhesive film widely used in superficial wounds, pressure sores, minor cuts and as a secondary dressing. Benefits Waterproof Allows permeability to moisture and vapours Allows visualisation of the wound Acts as a barrier to bacteria Highly extensible and comfortable Less risk of allergy Reduced risk of maceration, pain and blistering on removal
  • • It’s a transparent, adhesive film widely used in superficial wounds, pressure sores, minor cuts and as a secondary dressing.
  • • Benefits Waterproof Allows permeability to moisture and vapours Allows visualisation of the wound Acts as a barrier to bacteria Highly extensible and comfortable Less risk of allergy Reduced risk of maceration, pain and blistering on removal
  • • Waterproof Allows permeability to moisture and vapours Allows visualisation of the wound Acts as a barrier to bacteria Highly extensible and comfortable Less risk of allergy Reduced risk of maceration, pain and blistering on removal
  • • Waterproof
  • • Allows permeability to moisture and vapours
  • • Allows visualisation of the wound
  • • Acts as a barrier to bacteria
  • • Highly extensible and comfortable
  • • Less risk of allergy
  • • Reduced risk of maceration, pain and blistering on removal

questions.text: True regarding Spigelian hernias

options.label: A
options.text: Arise at lateral border of rectus abdominis

options.label: B
options.text: Originate where the transversus abdominis is absent

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Spigelian hernias
  • • Hernia through the Spigelian fascia, close to the level of the arcuate line, lateral to the rectus abdominis muscle. A type of interparietal hernias Cause is a defect in the transversus abdominis and rectus sheath aponeurosis Can be congenital or acquired Right> Left sided May be painful swelling CT is diagnostic Surgery always indicated as high risk of strangulation
  • • Hernia through the Spigelian fascia, close to the level of the arcuate line, lateral to the rectus abdominis muscle.
  • • A type of interparietal hernias
  • • Cause is a defect in the transversus abdominis and rectus sheath aponeurosis
  • • Can be congenital or acquired
  • • Right> Left sided
  • • May be painful swelling
  • • CT is diagnostic
  • • Surgery always indicated as high risk of strangulation

questions.text: After long segment ileal resection with competent and sparedileocaecal valve, which of the following is/are seen?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Short bowel syndrome has been arbitrarily defined as the presence of less than 200 cm of residual small bowel in adultpatients Resection of less than 50% of the small intestine is generally well tolerated. However, clinically significant malabsorption occurs when greater than 50% to 80% of the small intestine has been resected.Steatorrhea, cholelithiasis, oxalate kidney stones and nutritional deficiencies are all known manifestations.

questions.text: True regarding phylloides tumour of breast is/are?

options.label: C
options.text: Second most common benign tumour of breast

options.label: D
options.text: Can be reliably diagnosed by FNAC

options.label: E
options.text: Treated by wide local excision or mastectomy

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Phylloides tumour/Cystosarcomaphylloides
  • • Rare, mostly benign tumour seen in the female breast. It is the most common non-epithelial neoplasm of the breast 58% are benign, 12% are borderline malignant and 20% are frankly malignant Most common in females aged 40-50 years Firm, palpable mass with a bosselated surface is common presentation. Rapidly grow in size and overlying skin may be tense and shiny with dilated veins No LN involvement is seen FNAC not sufficient, require open excisional biopsy for making the diagnosis Surgical treatment involves local excision in small tumours and mastectomy in larger lesions, with no need for axillary LN dissection.
  • • Rare, mostly benign tumour seen in the female breast.
  • • It is the most common non-epithelial neoplasm of the breast
  • • 58% are benign, 12% are borderline malignant and 20% are frankly malignant
  • • Most common in females aged 40-50 years
  • • Firm, palpable mass with a bosselated surface is common presentation.
  • • Rapidly grow in size and overlying skin may be tense and shiny with dilated veins
  • • No LN involvement is seen
  • • FNAC not sufficient, require open excisional biopsy for making the diagnosis
  • • Surgical treatment involves local excision in small tumours and mastectomy in larger lesions, with no need for axillary LN dissection.

questions.text: TTrue regarding hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is/are?

options.label: C
options.text: Hemangioma is more common primary liver tumour than HCC

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A is true. Elevated AFP are seen in 50-75% cases Option B is false. Only 15-20% cases are resectable because of multicentricity, bilobar involvement, portal vein invasion and lymphatic metastasis Option C is False. HCC is most common primary liver malignancy
  • • Option A is true. Elevated AFP are seen in 50-75% cases
  • • Option B is false. Only 15-20% cases are resectable because of multicentricity, bilobar involvement, portal vein invasion and lymphatic metastasis
  • • Option C is False. HCC is most common primary liver malignancy
  • • Option D is true. Vascular invasion of portal channels is very common in HCC

questions.text: True regarding 1-0 suture as compared to 10-0 suture is/are?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Larger the number ascribed, smaller the diameter, so 10-0 suture will have a smaller diameter than 1-0 suture
  • • Larger the number ascribed, smaller the diameter, so 10-0 suture will have a smaller diameter than 1-0 suture
  • • Larger the number ascribed, lower is the tensile strength, so 10-0 suture will be weaker than 1-0 suture

questions.text: True regarding epidural hematoma is/are?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Epidural hematoma (EDH)
  • • Accumulation of blood between skull and duramater, laterally along the cerebral convexities Bleeding from the middle meningeal artery in 90% cases Traumatic point of impact commonly at the pterion, which is the weakest part of the skull Lucid interval present Features of raised ICP rapidly develop and progress after the lucid interval; More dangerous than SDH Biconvex lenticular appearance seen on CT scan Urgent surgery is indicated
  • • Accumulation of blood between skull and duramater, laterally along the cerebral convexities
  • • Bleeding from the middle meningeal artery in 90% cases
  • • Traumatic point of impact commonly at the pterion, which is the weakest part of the skull
  • • Lucid interval present
  • • Features of raised ICP rapidly develop and progress after the lucid interval;
  • • More dangerous than SDH
  • • Biconvex lenticular appearance seen on CT scan
  • • Urgent surgery is indicated

  • • Most common benign tumour in stomach
  • • Types Hyperplastic: 75%, non malignant, seen in antrum Adenomatous: 20%, can be malignant, seen in antrum Rare forms: 5%, can be fundic, juvenile polyps etc.
  • • Hyperplastic: 75%, non malignant, seen in antrum Adenomatous: 20%, can be malignant, seen in antrum Rare forms: 5%, can be fundic, juvenile polyps etc.
  • • Hyperplastic: 75%, non malignant, seen in antrum
  • • Adenomatous: 20%, can be malignant, seen in antrum
  • • Rare forms: 5%, can be fundic, juvenile polyps etc.
  • • Mostly asymptomatic Surgery done only in symptomatic polyps, >2 cm size or in adenomatous polyps
  • • Mostly asymptomatic
  • • Surgery done only in symptomatic polyps, >2 cm size or in adenomatous polyps
